page.title: 02HALL AND GROUNDS HOUGHTON.
page.content: In a park of 397 acres stands Houghton Hall built in a Palladian style between 1722 &1735 for Robert Walpole,chief minister to George 2nd. Original designs were by COLEN CAMPBELL and revised by THOMAS RIPLEY, who also took charge of the building. Locally made brick was used for the shell of the house but it was sheathed in ashlared AISLABY sandstone,from Whitby in Yorkshire.WILLIAM KENT took charge of interior decoration and furnishing.The stuccoist ,ARTARI, and the sculptor,EYSBRACK, worked under Kents direction.Tax was removed from the import of mahogany in 172O and the original HONDURAS mahogany is to be found in the doors, shutters, staircase and some furniture.The stable block was faced with the local CARR stone chiefly quarried at SNETTISHAM.
